ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class focuses on analysis of aquatic chemistry systems.
acid base chem, weathering, redox reactions, solubility, complexation and speciation
I gained the skills to understand the ways in which chemical compounds interact in aquatic environments.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lectures are incredibly disorganized and confusing. The class is mostly going through examples, but the professor never really explains what the goal of the examples are, so it just feels like a series of calculations with no broader sense of the goal of the problem or the significance of the results.

i think this class would be better fit as a flipped course with class time for questions. one lecture was conducted this way and was more efficient in my opinion. watching gabe write through all the reactions and graphing can be kind of slow/ painstaking at times.

The strengths of this course lie in the content. The weaknesses of this course lie in the instruction. The professor was disorganized, not knowing when exams where to take place and not providing sufficient resources.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: the in class camera/black board situation was good and bad. good because it felt more like a real classroom and allowed gabe to teach in a way he is used to. sometimes it was hard to see or he would move the camera before i could finish writing.
The single recorded lecture for this course was easier to follow than the live lectures. In the future, if taught virtually, the class should be taught in a "flipped" format.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I would not recommend this class unless you absolutely must. I did not look forward to going to this class because the lectures were so incredibly disorganized and confusing. The professor often made mistakes in his lectures, which was confusing and also frustrating because he would get annoyed at students for not having noticed and stopped him.  
The psets are not long and are doable, especially if you go to TA office hours.

I would not recommend this course to another student. The professor is disorganized and the office hours are few to none and held on days before the students have begun to work on the weekly problems sets.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There was a single recorded lecture.
